text: Beneficence — positive action for others' benefit — is morally admirable but cannot be compelled. Justice — the refraining from harming others — can and should be compelled. A society that tries to compel beneficence produces tyranny. A society that fails to enforce justice produces exploitation.
notes: Converges with Frankl vf_014 on freedom and responsibility as paired.

author: Adam Smith
text: Custom and fashion have an enormous influence on moral judgment — far more than most moral philosophers acknowledge. What counts as appropriate grief, appropriate ambition, appropriate sensuality varies dramatically across cultures and across time. Smith is not a relativist but he is honest about the extent to which custom shapes what the impartial spectator finds appropriate.
notes: Converges with Montaigne mm_016 on custom as the most powerful shaper of judgment and Pascal bp_016 on the unexamined foundations of most moral convictions.

author: Adam Smith
text: The virtues Smith most admires are not the heroic virtues — courage, magnificence, great public achievement. They are the virtues of the ordinary moral life: prudence, justice, beneficence toward those in one's community, and the self-command that allows all the others to function under pressure.
notes: Converges with Marcus Aurelius ma_008 on virtue as the same whether witnessed or not and Aristotle ar_010 on virtue as habit.

author: Adam Smith
text: Self-command — the capacity to moderate your emotions appropriately, to neither suppress them entirely nor be overwhelmed by them — is the foundational virtue for Smith because it is the precondition for all the others. Without self-command, prudence collapses into calculation, justice into rigidity, and beneficence into sentimentality.
notes: Converges with Aristotle ar_007 on virtue as stable disposition and Gita bg_017 on the mind as friend or enemy depending on its discipline.

author: Adam Smith
text: We admire the children of the wealthy not because they are more virtuous or capable but because we imaginatively project onto them the happiness we associate with their wealth. This is a systematic error of the moral imagination — mistaking the trappings of wealth for the substance of wellbeing — and it drives the pursuit of wealth beyond any rational purpose it could serve.
notes: Converges with Boethius bo_005 on false goods and Thoreau ht_006 on possessions possessing their owner.

author: Adam Smith
text: There is a fundamental tension in Smith's system that he acknowledges but does not resolve: the impartial spectator, properly consulted, would endorse the modest virtuous life over the ambitious wealth-seeking one. But the desire for wealth and distinction is what drives the economic activity in which all flourish. The engine of progress is a form of self-deception Smith calls the deception of nature.
notes: Most honest moment in the book. Generates direct contradicts edge with Smith's own economic framework and mirrors Becker eb_013 on the vital lie — both describing a necessary and productive self-deception at the heart of human civilisation.

author: Adam Smith
text: The man of system — the political reformer who believes he can arrange society's pieces according to his rational plan — imagines he can move human beings like pieces on a chessboard, forgetting that each piece has its own principle of motion. The worst political outcomes are produced not by malice but by the man of system's confidence in his own scheme.
notes: Converges with Kierkegaard sk_015 on the crowd as untruth and Dostoevsky fd_018 on cold ideology as more dangerous than passionate sin.

author: Adam Smith
text: Approbation — the approval of others — is what human beings most fundamentally desire. Not pleasure in the narrow sense, not wealth, not power — but the sense that we are seen favorably by those whose opinion matters to us. A moral philosophy that ignores this will consistently misunderstand why people actually do what they do.
notes: Mirrors Pascal bp_021 on the overestimation of others' opinions and Thoreau ht_021 on public opinion as the most powerful and least examined force in human life.

author: Adam Smith
text: The Theory of Moral Sentiments is an empirical moral philosophy — it begins not with what people should feel but with what they actually feel, and builds its normative claims on that foundation. Taking observed human psychology seriously as the starting point for moral philosophy rather than as an obstacle to be overcome by reason is Smith's most important philosophical innovation.
notes: Mirrors Darwin cd_003 on the moral sense as evolved rather than rational — both insisting that moral philosophy must start from what humans actually are rather than from what they should be according to a prior theory.

author: Adam Smith
text: The poor man's son works his entire life pursuing wealth and distinction, believing these will bring the happiness he imagines the wealthy possess. He attains them in old age and discovers they are empty. He has sacrificed the health, leisure, and genuine relationships that actually constitute wellbeing in pursuit of something that, properly understood, he never wanted at all.
notes: Converges with Boethius bo_005 on false goods, Thoreau ht_003 on the cost measured in life, and Aristotle ar_016 on the self-defeating character of pleasure-seeking.

author: Adam Smith
text: Rank and distinction — the desire to be noticed, to be attended to, to be seen as superior — is a more powerful motivator than the desire for pleasure in any narrow sense. This is what most wealth-seeking is actually about. The rich do not primarily want comfort — they want regard.
notes: Strongest single cross-book converges edge in the Smith extraction — with Becker eb_008 on the universal need to feel heroic and Boethius bo_007 on fame as the most hollow of false goods.

author: Adam Smith
text: When a society admires the rich regardless of their virtue and dismisses the poor regardless of theirs — when the impartial spectator's judgment is systematically distorted by wealth — the entire moral infrastructure of society begins to fail. This is not primarily an economic problem. It is a moral and psychological one.
notes: Converges with Becker eb_009 on the quality of a civilisation measured by the quality of its illusions and Pascal bp_015 on power defining justice as whatever benefits it.

author: Adam Smith
text: The 'Adam Smith Problem' suggests a tension between the sympathy of the Theory of Moral Sentiments and the self-interest of the Wealth of Nations. However, modern interpretation identifies them as integrated: markets require a foundation of mutual sympathy and the 'impartial spectator' to function without collapsing into fraud or violence. Self-interest is an engine, but sympathy is the track.
notes: Integrates the moral foundation of sympathy (as_001) with the economic engine of interest (as_018) as a single coherent system.
